Show HN: Get conversational practice in over 20 languages by talking to an AI
text:
Hi everyone,

Let me introduce you to Quazel, where we want to enable people to talk their way to fluency.

We have all tried various language learning apps and tools, however, one aspect of language learning current services are really bad at is conversational practice. You might get a chat-like interface, but in the end, the conversation partner will only respond with a predefined "if the users say X I say Y".

With Quazel that's completely different. In completely dynamic and unscripted conversation you can talk about pretty much anything you want. For example, you can try ordering food at a restaurant and even hold a philosophical discussion with Socrates. Additionally, you can analyze the grammar of your responses or use hints to help you out when you get stuck.

We want to change how languages are learned from a grammar-centric approach to a more natural, conversation-focused one.

Ask HN: Which boring technology do you still use?
text:
This question is inspired by the Choose Boring Technology post that is posted here often. My question here is which boring technology do you still use?

The most interesting answers would be those where the majority of tech workers today would most likely choose a new shiny technology but you still use a boring technology for it. Please do provide some context for your answers. Why did you choose the boring technology? What problems do you solve with it? Why didn't you switch to another popular alternative for it?

title: Solar Panels Piling Up in Warehouses in Energy-Starved Europe
Show HN: Tool to check website for external scripts
text:
I worte a small tool to check for external script usage on your website for GDPR compliance. When I was CTO we used WGET to check if there were external scripts that made it somehow through review or introduced by marketing. With more and more European countries finding E.g. Google Fonts problematic, I thought there should be an easier way and created FuguFugu mainly as a weekend project. FuguFugu will scan your website and check for external scripts, images and CSS imports. Be kind, it has some rough edges, bugs and I'm still learning Go.

https://github.com/FuguFuguHq/fugufugu

What do you think? Open for feedback and ideas.
